What is the colour of your life?

10 Jul 2014

I experimented with multiple approaches to analyse my work. Only one of them stuck to me and have been helping me every day since then. Its major advantage is simplicity: I need to spend only 15 seconds per day.

Yeap, by spending only 15 seconds per day you could considerably improve your work. Interested? Keep reading!

Research

I’m going to give a talk “Unexpected Journey or How To Quit Your Job” in August at Agile Lean Europe. When I got an approval from the organizers, I thought, Can I give to people any tool they may use immediately after the conference? I loved one tool I’d been using for several months up to that moment. I wanted to test if the tool might be useful for others. I asked my colleagues and friends to use this approach and provide me a feedback.

Everything you find below is based on my own experience and the feedback from my colleagues and friends.

Description

There are two stages of the usage of the tool.

Initiation stage

Task 0: I hope you have at least one professional middle-/long-term goal. Write it down or draw it if you haven’t done it yet. The tool will work without a goal, but if you have one, you will create very useful connections with your everyday results and a goal. The impact will be bigger.

Task 1: think and define what it means for you — being satisfied with your work. Recall when your work brought you the highest satisfaction. What sides of your work make you happy? Write it down, no more than 3-5 points.

Task 2: find a calendar or buy one :).

Main stage

Every day you need to ask yourself just one question: ”Am I at least 75% satisfied with my past working day?”. If yes, paint the date over with a green colour. If no, a red one.

That’s all the magic!

It works

Unfortunately only a small percent of creative workers asks themselves regularly "How was my working day?" Several my colleagues pointed out that the requirement to answer the question motivates them to plan their day better to make it green at the end. Several others said this simple everyday analysis helped them to dissolve some issues they hadn't found time to deal with before.

Looking at longer period (a month or more), the tool reveals how your working life is going. Our brains is optimised for imagining the future, not reproducing the past. As a result we leave out many details recalling what happened a week ago. Besides this, our brains rank higher the events which took place a couple of days ago than two weeks old events. One good or bad day at the end of the month makes a bigger impact on the final month's score that the first two weeks.

The tool helps to visualise your working life and makes your retrospective more objective. Some of my colleagues found out their jobs were not that bad as they thought only after two weeks of playing with the tool.

There is no silver bullet

Of course, the tool won’t be useful for everyone. Some of you will find it valuable after the first week, some of you - only after the first month, and for some of you it will be useless. Here is what my colleagues and friends think about it after two week of the research:

Anonymous Author
I started to plan my day more seriously. When you have such explicit metric as "the satisfaction of the past day" it's easier to overcome your laziness. I also began to feel time better"
Simon Lyashenko
It disciplines me in some way as it plays a role of daily meeting. It's also useful that the upper limit is not 100%. You have some level of freedom which allows you to "feel comfortable" even if you couldn't do everything you planned
Denis Misharin
There is no value for me right now :). But at least it makes me look back at the past day in the beginning of the next one. And not to run further immediately :)
Lisette Sutherland
It would be nice to see all the scores at once, to get an idea of how happy I am at work overall - and over time.

Your next step

You may be a lone warrior and start using this approach all by yourself. Or…  you may join our group and get a daily email or a daily message in Facebook from me with the only question “Are you at least 75% satisfied with your past working day?”. It helps you to form a good habit faster and motivates you much more than a boring automatic reminder. 

Send me a message, join the group and colour your life in green!
